properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A vigorous cold front will sweep across the province this afternoon into this evening and may generate snow squalls as it passes. Periods of heavy snow are possible with the snow squalls, and visibilities may be greatly reduced under the intense snow. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for brief but intense bursts of heavy snow producing near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T01:38:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T09:39:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3297996084.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, strong winds, and blowing snow expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm, except 5 to 10 cm along parts of the coast. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except up to 120 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: this evening until Tuesday afternoon. Remarks: Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:15:52-00:00

Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potentially damaging winds today. Winds have eased from their peak last night. However, winds are forecast to strengthen once again this morning, particularly along the shorelines of Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. Gusts up to 90 km/h can be expected from late morning through early afternoon. Winds will slowly ease later this afternoon into this evening. Power outages are possible. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T01:38:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T09:39:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1205989257.2021
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Bayfield Inlet - Dunchurch, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls this afternoon through tonight. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to develop today with the arrival of an unseasonably cold airmass. Locally heavy snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm will be possible today. By tonight, as the winds shift to a more northwesterly direction, snow squalls will become more confined to areas east of the Blue Mountains and west of Barrie, likely impacting the communities of Collingwood and Wasaga Beach. An additional 10 to 15 cm will be possible in these areas by the time the snow squalls weaken late tonight. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will also accompany the snow squalls this afternoon and early this evening, resulting in reduced visibilities in heavy snow and blowing snow. Given the strength of the winds and falling temperatures with time, blowing snow will be common under any snow squall that forms. Motorists should be prepared for adverse winter driving conditions and adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T01:48:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T09:49:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2020151636.2021
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 to 120 km/h with higher gusts in the Wreckhouse area. Locations: Codroy Valley eastward to the Francois area. Time span: this evening until Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:15:13-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: This evening, the arrival of an Arctic air mass will cause temperatures to fall dramatically, going from plus 2 degrees Celsius to minus 12 degrees Celsius in a few hours. Cold wind chills values near minus 30 are expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Local snow squalls this afternoon through tonight. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to develop today with the arrival of an unseasonably cold airmass. Locally heavy snowfall amounts up to 15 cm today and another 15 to 25 cm tonight will be possible by the time the snow squalls weaken late tonight. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will also accompany the snow squalls, resulting in reduced visibilities in heavy snow and blowing snow. Given the strength of the winds and falling temperatures, significantly reduced visibilities in blowing snow will be common under any snow squall that forms, making travel difficult. Motorists should be prepared for adverse winter driving conditions and adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, strong winds, and blowing snow are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: Connaigre, Burin, and southern Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: overnight tonight until midday Tuesday. Remarks: The snow and blowing snow are expected to change to a brief period of rain late Tuesday morning before changing back to flurries in the afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, strong winds and blowing snow expected Tuesday. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland and the northern Avalon Peninsula. Total snowfall: possibly exceeding 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h or higher. Time span: Tuesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across Newfoundland on Tuesday, in combination with strong southeasterly winds and blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Local snow squalls possible this afternoon through tonight. A few heavy flurries are possible this morning. However, by this afternoon, locally heavy snow squalls are expected to develop with the arrival of an unseasonably cold airmass. Locally heavy snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by the time the snow squalls weaken tonight. The heavy snow will combine with strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h resulting in reduced visibilities in heavy snow and blowing snow at times. Motorists should be prepared for adverse winter driving conditions and adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 40 are expected overnight tonight. An Arctic air mass combined with moderate winds will produce extreme cold conditions. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Intense snow squall possible late this morning and this afternoon. A relatively narrow, but intense snow squall is forecast to develop this morning and then move across the area late this morning through this afternoon. Locally heavy snowfall will occur with this snow squall, resulting in a quick 5 to 10 cm of new accumulation. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will also occur this afternoon. These strong winds will combine with the heavy snow to result in reduced visibilities in blowing snow and difficult travel conditions over portions of the area. The snow squall is expected to move south of the region by this evening. Motorists are advised to exercise caution. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-03-01. An intense low pressure system from New England will give strong winds over the regions listed below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time): Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier: 2021-03-01, from 01:30 PM to 04:30 PM. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T01:59:34-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts of 30 to 50 centimetres as well as strong winds and blowing snow are expected until Tuesday. Snow at times heavy will begin this morning. During the day, winds up to 80 kilometres per hour will reduce visibilities to nil in widespread blowing snow. High winds could reach up to 110 kilometres per hour in the Blanc-Sablon area and give zero visibilities in blowing snow beginning early Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:18:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:19:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2077877356.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 80 km/h, except 100 over exposed areas. Locations: the Bonavista and northern Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: Tuesday morning until Tuesday evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:14:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:15:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3357154249.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Bonavista Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: By this afternoon, the arrival of an Arctic air mass will cause temperatures to fall dramatically, going from near the freezing mark to minus 16 degrees Celsius in a few hours. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T20:26:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T11:27:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0593660674.2021
Area: Dorval Lodge area, Le Domaine area, Chibougamau, Gouin Reservoir area, Parent area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected on Tuesday. By Tuesday, between 20 and 40 centimetres of snow, along with strong winds and blowing snow, are expected. Beginning overnight tonight through Tuesday morning, intense wind chill values will cause temperatures to feel like near minus 30. Tuesday, westerly winds will intensify and cause widespread blowing snow and visibilities reduced to zero. Wind gusts will reach up to 110 km/h over the northern shore of the Gaspé peninsula. Consider modifying any non-essential travel plans. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:16:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:17:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3088302840.2021
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Murdochville area, Mont-Albert area, Grande-Rivière - Cascapédia area, Baie-Comeau
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 140 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: this evening until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Southeasterly winds gusting to 100 km/h will develop this evening then increase to 140 km/h overnight. Winds will ease upon shifting to strong southwesterly Tuesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:15:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:16:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1990187242.2021
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2021-03-01. An intense low pressure system from New England will give strong to high winds over the regions specified below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time): Kamouraska - Rivière-du-Loup - Trois-Pistoles: 2021-03-02, from 03:00 AM to 07:00 AM. Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2021-03-02, from 02:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Matane: 2021-03-02, from 02:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallée: 2021-03-02, from 02:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Natashquan: 2021-03-01, from 11:00 PM to 03:00 AM. Chevery: 2021-03-01, from 10:00 PM to 02:00 AM. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T04:01:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T12:02:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0410970488.2021
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Natashquan, Chevery, Trois-Pistoles area, Kamouraska area, Rivière-du-Loup area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Lake effect snow bands are producing near zero visibilities at times this morning. Local snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm will be possible by the time snow squall activity weakens late this afternoon. The heavy snow, combining with strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h, will continue to produce near zero visibilities in heavy snow and blowing snow. Motorists should prepare for adverse winter driving conditions and adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T02:06:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T13:34:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1307517484.2021
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Light north winds combined with temperatures in the mid minus forties will result in wind chill values of -55 or lower on Monday morning. Wind chill values will moderate slightly Monday afternoon however extreme wind chill values are expected to return to the area Monday night into Tuesday morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T01:25:00-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. High wind gusts of 90 km/h will continue throughout the day. Winds will weaken this evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
